titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Gates Percival Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:56

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The James Gates Percival Collection consist of writings, notebooks, personal papers, correspondence, maps, and other papers that document Percival's life and work. Writings are autograph manuscripts of poetry and prose compositions on linguistics, geology, and geography, including several drafts of his Report on the Geology of Connecticut, as well as chemistry notes by West Point professor James Cutbush. Percival's notebooks contain writings and notes on a broad range of topics in addition to his classroom notes from school, college, and medical school days. Personal papers include contracts, agreements, and subscriber lists related to his publications; inventories and invoices documenting his large library collection; and other financial papers, primarily bills for personal expenses including room, board, and clothing. Correspondence files hold letters to and from many prominent colleagues and scholars such as Benjamin Silliman and Edward C. Herrick in New Haven, friends including George Hayward in Boston, his publishers Sidney Babcock, Samuel G. Goodrich, and Samuel Walker, and editors such as Eliza Leslie and Louisa C. Tuthill. Percival was a member of the New Haven Sing-Song Club and the collection documents his contributions to that organization. Also present is a portrait painting of Percival by his brother Edwin Percival, and a group of papers regarding Percival's life and work complied by J. H. Ward, Herbert E. Gregory, and others, including a memoir of him by Caroline Howard Gilman.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Julius H. Ward (Yale 1860), after 1866. Other acquisitions are noted at the folder level.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Althea Green Wilson discusses the history of Percival's papers in the Yale University Library Gazette 28 (no. 2, October 1953). Several of the items in the collection were published in J. H. Ward's volume The Life and Letters of James Gates Percival (Boston: Ticknor and Fields, 1866).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James Gates Percival Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Gates Percival Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained, as has the arrangement of the material and the corresponding catalog numbers assigned by former library staff members. Some of the manuscripts were annotated by Donald Gallup, curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature. A folder with photocopies of the Percival catalog cards is filed in the front of box 1.
Former call numbers: Za Percival, Uncat Za File Percival, Iw P412 +1, Za P412 +1, Za P412 +S1, Art Storage 698, Za Objects 38, u.1927.132

bioghist.head: James Gates Percival (1795-1856)
bioghist.p: James Gates Percival, an American poet, physician, linguist, geologist, bibliophile, and autodidact, was born in Kensington, Connecticut, on September 15, 1795. After attending boarding school he entered Yale College in 1810 and graduated in 1815. Percival began medical school at the University of Pennsylvania in 1818 but returned to Yale to complete his degree in 1820. He practiced medicine in Connecticut and Charleston, South Carolina, and briefly taught chemistry at West Point in 1824. Returning to Connecticut, he studied linguistics and European languages (particularly German), assisted Noah Webster with his American Dictionary of the English Language (1828), and prepared new editions of Vicesimus Knox's Elegant Extracts (1826) and Conrad Malte-Brun's A System of Universal Geography (1834). His former Yale professor and mentor Benjamin Silliman encouraged Percival's appointment as Connecticut state geologist in 1835, which led to his amassing great quantities of geological data that were eventually published in his volume Report on the Geology of the State of Connecticut (1842). Hired to survey lead mines in Illinois and Wisconsin in 1853, Percival spent his last years in the Midwest, becoming the state geologist of Wisconsin in 1854; he died in Hazel Green, Wisconsin, on May 2, 1856.

Percival began writing poetry while in boarding school, his most notable work being the epic-length poem "The Commerciad"; later verses were published in the early 1820s in the New Haven Microscope , the United States Literary Gazette , and other newspapers. His collected Poems (1821) included his well-regarded "Prometheus" and inspired the publication of Prometheus Part II with Other Poems (1822). His series Clio I , Clio II (both 1822), and Clio III (1827) were followed fifteen years later by his final volume of poetry, The Dream of a Day (1843).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James Gates Percival Papers consist of writings, notebooks, personal papers, correspondence, maps, and other papers. Writings are autograph manuscripts of poetry and prose compositions on linguistics, geology, and geography, including several drafts of his Report on the Geology of Connecticut , as well as chemistry notes by West Point professor James Cutbush. Percival's notebooks contain writings and notes on a broad range of topics in addition to classroom notes from school, college, and his medical school days. Personal papers include contracts, agreements, and subscriber lists related to his publications, inventories and invoices documenting his large library collection, and other financial papers, primarily bills for personal expenses including room, board, and clothing. Correspondence files hold letters to and from many prominent colleagues and scholars such as Benjamin Silliman and Edward C. Herrick in New Haven, friends including George Hayward in Boston, his publishers Sidney Babcock, Samuel G. Goodrich, and Samuel Walker, and editors such as Eliza Leslie and Louisa C. Tuthill. Percival was a member of the New Haven Sing-Song Club and the collection documents his contributions to that organization. Also present is a portrait painting of Percival by his brother Edwin Percival, and small groups of papers regarding Percival's life and work complied by J. H. Ward, Herbert E. Gregory, and others, including a memoir of him by Caroline Howard Gilman.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Writings, 1800-1854. II. Notebooks and Notes, 1807-1840. III. Personal Papers, 1819-1851. IV. Correspondence, 1816-1856. V. Printed Material, 1822-1856. VI. Maps and Artwork, 1830-1840. VII. Other Papers Related to Percival and His Work, 1859-1944.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into five subseries: Poetry, Linguistics, Prose, Geology, Geography, and Other Topics; within those subseries material is arranged by the consecutive numbers assigned by library staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains autograph manuscripts by Percival that include his literary and scientific work. The folders hold drafts and notes as well as finished compositions meant for publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript of preface and first canto. 85[5] pages. Page 74-[89] miscellaneous poems and verses unpublished. Last leaf has list of militia personnel by towns with distance from Boston.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into two subseries: Notebooks and Notes; within those subseries material is arranged by the consecutive numbers assigned by library staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of a set of volumes in which Percival recorded his schoolwork, his poems, the books in his library, his expenses for trips taken, and notes on a variety of topics including linguistics. Prominent among them are his notes on the geology of Connecticut (which complements material in Box 3) and item number 420, which records of his dealings with his publishers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written at the age of 16. Series of long poems intended to include the four seasons, but not finished. Inscribed inside back cover: Philadelphia Dec 1815.

did.unittitle: 401. Latin language notes and a bibliography of language of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Mr. Silliman's private lectures on mineralogy. - Mr. Kingsley's lectures on history. - Husbandry. - Botany. - A view of the natural order of Linnaeus from the Encyclopedia Britannica. - System of Nature by Charles Line. - Additional genera from Shaw's General Zoology. - Murray's Chemistry. - Chemistry. - A course of Natural Science.

did.unittitle: 403. College notes chiefly on the sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Disputes and decisions by Dr. Dwight. - British poets. - Scotch airs and words adapted to them. - Diseases of children, Ives. - Dr. Ives on Materia Medica. - Dr. Smith on Nervous Diseases. - Botany notes.

did.unittitle: 404. College notes on Benjamin Silliman's chemistry lectures 1-84
405. College notes and later linguistic bibliographies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: System of Rhetoric compiled from Blair's lectures and Dr. Dwight's remarks - Logic - Moral Philosophy - Dr. Dwight's advice. - Linguistic bibliographies - Disputations. - Mr. Kingsley on languages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Disputations - Linne's Systema Natura - Submersed algae from Dilwynn's Conservae. - System of theology from Vincent to Dr. Dwight - Wilson's Ornithology. - Linguistic bibliography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript notes on his readings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Zoology compiled from Shaw, Buffon, Pennant. - Mithradates vol. II, European languages vol. III, African languages - American languages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: To a young lady who had lent me Hayley's Triumphs of Temper. - Ode to melancholy. - Ode to fancy. - On viewing one summer evening the house of my nativity in a state of desertion. - Sonnets. - To a rose. - Ode on death. - Elegy. - Ode for the Fourth of July. - Ode to music. - On hearing a lady singing in the tow-r of Montevideo. - On the death of Miss __ who was drowned while bathing on Rockaway Beach. - Loch Maree. - On finding the Anamone Hepatica. - To the Gentiana Crinita the last flow-r of autumn. - To religion. - An imprecation. - Monody on Perry. - Other untitled verses. Many of these were first published in The Microscope , New Haven, 1820.

did.unittitle: 415. Catalog of books in his library, sales records of his Poems , linguistic notes, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents: Catalogue of books. - Contents of Irving's Sketch Book. - Delineation of Scotland; extracts from the Beauties of Scotland. - Poem to Scotland. - Sales record of his Poems. 1821 - Sismondi, Literature du midi de l'Europe. - Notes on Spanish, Portuguese, German, Danish, and Italian literature. - Ode von Goethe zum Herrn Byron. - Languages and alphabets. - Aikin's British poets. - Hazlett's British poets. - Alphabets used in Webster's Dictionary. - Botany notes. - Rules for printing Arabic. - Linguistic notes on Danish Swedish, Russian, English, Wallachian, Romaic, Bulgarian. - Questions on Polit. econ. - Scotch literati 1792 by William Creech. - Welch grammar.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized by the consecutive numbers assigned by library staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds many of Percival's financial papers documenting his payments for room, board, clothing, laundry, and other expenses, including his agreement with the General Hospital Society of Connecticut, where Percival lived from 1843 through 1851. Prominent among the papers are records related to his large collection of books: almost one hundred leaves of book inventories, more than twenty leaves of organizational schemes for the volumes, over eighty receipts from booksellers in Philadelphia, New York, Boston, and New Haven between 1819 and 1841, and insurance papers covering the collection. Also here are agreements regarding his publications, and a few general financial records. Other records for his publications and library are in Series II, Box 7, folder 140.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Letters from James Gates Percival; Letters to James Gates Percival; and Third-Party Correspondence; within those subseries material is arranged by the consecutive numbers assigned by library staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains a collection of correspondence to and from Percival which was acquired from various sources. Prominent among the correspondents are Dr. George Hayward of Boston, and Percival's publishers Sidney Babcock, Samuel G. Goodrich, and Samuel Walker.
Publication references noted are to J. H. Ward, The Life and Letters of James Gates Percival (Boston: Ticknor and Fields, 1866).

Woolsey (1821); Christopher Preston Barnum to his brother George (1841); Thomas Church Brownell to Richard Channing Moore (1825); Henry Waggaman Edwards to Luther Loomis (1840); Jeremiah Day (1821); Daniel Dunbar to Mary Ward, with rental agreement (1828); Charles Hooker to Dr. Simons (1842); J. L. Jenckes to F. E. Phelps (1854); William Leete Stone to D. S. Jones (undated); Nathaniel Sheldon Wheaton to Mr. Jarvis (1824); and Thomas Augustus Worrall to Dr. Jonas Underwood (1822).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 1 art storage item

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI primarily contains twenty-two hand-drawn maps in ink, graphite, and crayon on paper; several of the maps were annotated on their versos by Percival's biographer J. H. Ward. The nineteen maps of Connecticut record in minute detail data on the geology of the state, and may have been created for Percival's work Report on the Geology of the State of Connecticut (1842) or his Geological Reports on the Middletown Silver-lead mines, Middletown, Connecticut (1853). Another map is labeled on its verso "Trap and Sandstone of New Jersey" and is likely related to material in Box 3, folder 94 (Report on the Trap and sandstone of New Jersey).

The remaining two maps are of foreign lands: Scotland and northern Europe. The former was previously misidentified by the library as a map of Pennsylvania, probably due to the initials "Pa" (meaning parish) after each place name inscribed on it. The latter portrays parts of countries in northern Europe including Holland, France, Denmark, Germany, Prussia, and Austria. It may have been prepared for Percival's 1834 edition of Malte-Brun's System of Universal Geography ; it was inscribed on the verso by Ward: Documents showing Percival's studies, but of no quotable or practical value J. H. W.

Also here is a portrait painting of Percival by his brother Edwin Percival. He was born in Kensington, Connecticut, in 1793, studied art in Hartford, Connecticut, and died in greatly reduced circumstances in Troy, New York, about 1847.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Chester R. Longwell (Yale PhD 1920), 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds small groups of material that document Percival's life. It includes some of J. H. Ward's correspondence and research notes, a folder of material regarding Percival collected by Herbert E. Gregory, and other manuscript and printed material written about Percival, including a memoir by Caroline Howard Gilman.
